reviews.advice: From the Chinese members of staff who are managing international employees or teams, more understanding of other cultures and people needs to be encouraged, as they make up a big proportion of the business. Diversity training is a must as well so that they are equipped to deal with any problems that may arise from managing a culturally and ethnically rich team of employees.
reviews.cons:
- Chinese staff and International staff were often divided into two separate offices (with the exception of local teachers who would share the same office as the international teachers). Team building activities were separated, celebrations were often separated, miscommunication was a common problem due to lack of mixing. It's entirely possible to work at a centre and not interact with about 1/3 of the staff there (there are three teams usually; Sales, Service, and Education). A shame by design, as EF's intended context from onboarding is that all staff are meant to pursue positive collaboration across all teams to function optimally. 

- EF marketing needs to be more ethnically diverse in 2020. The company in China gives the impression that they only employ ethnically white members of staff, which causes undue confusion to customers, clients, and even staff themselves when they see an employee of a different ethnic group - particularly of a darker complexion (on a bad day it also attracts derogatory comments towards the teachers). This is especially important as EF China in the past couple of years have started to recruit teachers from South Africa, where people of a darker complexion are certainly more prevalent, and should be respected.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your feedback and recommending us as an employer. We have recognized the need for a specific focus on diversity and inclusion, and due to our staff's feedback and management's support there have been multiple DEIB (Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging) Teams created across regions. For the Asia Team, training staff and reviewing marketing, is part of our strategy plan for the upcoming fiscal year. We also agree that there should be more cross cultural communication and collaboration between departments. If you feel comfortable discussing your feedback in more detail, feel free to confidentially connect with our team through teacher.welfare@ef.cn. The DEIB Asia team can also be reached at deib.asia@ef.cn.

reviews.pros:
- Company subsidised formal training recognised internationally. 
- Regional events for staff to attend subsidized or paid-for activities. 
- Pay was reasonable in proportion to responsibilities (for International staff).
- Teaching teams were often close-knit and positive communities in nature.

reviews.advice: EF could be a decent company if they learnt to be open to ideas and improvements. Also, please stop pushing these articles and stories about the founder of EF. It's embarrassing and it's only making the company look mre like a cult.
reviews.cons:
Really really disorganised
Staff who have been working at EF for a while (some of the were EF students) are really REALLY stuck up.

 I used to work at a another international summer school (the only reason I started working with EF instead is because my former summer school was not openning for this summer) so I know that disorganisation is quite natural in summer schools. However, at my former company staff were always making fun of how crazy and disorganised it was, so it was kind of an ongoing joke (at some point I believe one has to laugh when things go wrong sometimes). At EF things are very cult-like: they keep telling us ' it doesn't matter if everything is ridiculously disorganised, just don't talk about it'. Returning staff have this really weird loyalty to EF. They don't seem to care that simple things which shouldn't be going wrong ARE going wrong. They keep saying ' oh it's just EF'. So you can't say anything bad about EF because they are so sensitive about it.

At my other company, I always got food included in my accommodation fee, we never had to sleep in bunkbed rooms(we always had individual rooms), senior staff did not pay for accommodation because they had the responsability of being on 'emergency call'. At EF you have lots of residential responsabilities, but they would not offer you free accommodation or a discounted price at least. Again, at my other company, some Activity Leaders would become 'guardians' (responsible for students who came to the school without a group and unaccompanied by an adult). In this case, it was considered that the guardian MUST live in the accommodation because they have this extra responsability and therefore, they would be exempt of the accommodation fee.

 At EF it's all about appearances. They would be complaining about the bratty studets behind closed doores but then would go out of their way to buy students pizzas, cakes and McDonalds so that they would get good reviews. We literally had a 1 hour meeting just to talk about how incredibly important it is to get the highest score of student satisfaction. Thye do not really care if the students are having a good time. As long as they are having a good time 'on paper' then it's fine with EF which I find very phony and disingenuous. They know what the problems are but they are just delusional.
reviews.pros:
Met some wonderful people.
Creative and varied role suitable for somebody who likes multitasking and who gets bored easily
reviews.summary: I feel sad saying it, but it truely was the worst company I have ever worked at.

reviews.advice: I really don't know what  to say here.
reviews.cons: Had to get a lawyer to retrieve my social security payments and holiday pay.  However, I don't blame EF as a company, just the Spanish side of the business who knew what they were doing when the concealed my holiday pay and failed to pay my social security.  After legal representation they agreed to pay all outstanding amounts to both myself and the other teacher on the project.  I really felt so betrayed by EF after all the hard work and commitment I had given to representing them and promoting their name.
reviews.pros: A good opportunity to work on a project with an international company.
reviews.summary: EF Spain - Had to get a lawyer

reviews.advice: try to care more about your employees and measure all merits instead of indiscriminate decisions made...numbers can be great you should look at the customer satisfaction...not constantly creating a culture of fear of losing your job
reviews.cons: poor communication, low pay, lack of guidance and management doesn't seem to care about you, only your numbers. Even if your numbers are high they turn on you
reviews.pros: Tons of work available set your own schedule, easy to use tech infrastructure with adobe classroom and provided lesson plans
reviews.summary: Lots of work available, low pay and little support

reviews.advice:
Transparency transparency transparency 
Turnover is huge and employee morale is declining, maybe fix that too?
reviews.cons:
ALL the cons outlined by others are all 100% true.
However, Main CON is management. 

Extremely unskilled  /cannot manage 
Managers across the departments play favourites
Kinda like wolves in sheep skin 
Certain employees who cause issues and stress to others have been kept around for years merely because they help bring in sales" not because they are good people.

Tend to dispose of employees without warning 
HR NON-EXISTENT. 
They will ask for feedback every week, month , year  but nothing changes.
reviews.pros:
Office location
Vacation time 
Travel perks if you are in sales! 
Great place to work if you don't make mistakes!
reviews.summary: Good from far but FAR from good!

reviews.advice:
Of course, more money would be great but that decision comes directly from the investor. For managers there needs to be a more narrow focus of responsibilities and less pressure.

Only hire people who bring the right attitude! ;-)

Thank you for everything!
reviews.cons:
If you are interested in finding the job with the most money, then this isn't for you. If you learn and grow here, it is possible to be promoted - but still, even the promotion, even with all the opportunities it offers, doesn't come with a big chunk of money. However, if you keep going then the professional experience you gain can turn into big bucks down the road. Trust me.

As a manager, I was overworked. The local staff also have a lot to do. But I think the foreign teachers get a really good deal (definitely fewer hours than the average job back home, and much more enjoyable too!)
reviews.pros:
During my time at EF, I worked for three centers as well as in the Shanghai Headquarters. Here's the truth: EF Changshu hijacked my heart for life, and nothing else I've ever been a part of quite compares to the fellowship and camaraderie you feel on the adventure.

For me, the experience was everything that I'd hoped it would be and more...

The location is perfect for an authentic Chinese experience - in the centre you get all the buzz and electric vibe of an Oriental metropolis, and of course the city's gardens and teahouses preserve the elegance of the traditional China we all read about and see in the movies. The best part is that the school is directly opposite a stunning mountain and park!

The HR department (bless them) take care of you so much. They help you with your apartment, your banking, your phone, taxis, finding your way around the city... They saved me so many times and I couldn't thank them enough!

You get the consistent training, the ongoing feedback, and the professional support to strengthen your skills as a teacher and even build your career. That's how I ended up working in the Shanghai Headquarters.

Everyone in the school really makes sure that it's more than a job. It turns into such an enjoyable experience because you're around people who you build a connection with and who actually care. The atmosphere is just like being with a bunch of friends. It turns into a joy and I've certainly missed the place and the people since I left.

reviews.advice:
- Start caring about your staff, people are not invisible
- Put your nose in what we do and how, not only the big picture
- learn the name of your staff
reviews.cons:
- Management hire people from outside instead of promoting : they have no clue what Operational staff does (but they pretend they do through useless meetings)
- Extremely low salary for Switzerland
- Overtime is highly necessary if you want to do your job well (be careful lots of people burn out)
- Management do not care about people
- Result don’t matter: what matters is how much you pretend you love EF
reviews.pros:
- Tons of responsibilities that allow you to build your CV 
- There is so much staff turnover that you will become an expert in Recruitment (no matter your title)

reviews.cons: For some reason, the salary is lower than the industry standard for training schools in China. After you have gained enough confidence and experience in teaching, you really should move on to a higher paying job.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for your candid feedback. We take great pride in our teacher training programs and materials, and, we are very happy to hear that you feel we successfully develop our teachers. We care a lot about the culture of our centers and work hard to ensure teachers have a great experience. It's good to know that you enjoyed the teambuilding events and felt supported by your colleagues and managers. In terms of salary we do review our package regularly to ensure teachers are able to live comfortably. We also offer a competitive benefits package as well as ongoing teacher training and development.

reviews.pros: This is a great company to work at if you are brand new to teaching in China and need to build up your skills and experience. Multimedia teaching materials are excellent and the newly renovated facilities are very nice.  Management team and local staff are generally very friendly, helpful and supportive. Team-building events and outings are usually quite fun.

reviews.advice: Work on the travel expenses refund system and make sure that employer received their contract or info about these in advance so that they can plan their lives!
reviews.cons: Everything is so disorganised, the payroll takes ages to do anything and the HR is just a big mess where the recruiting manager never replies to the emails and gives away contracts the day before these are supposed to start giving little if none info to the employee.
reviews.pros: The teaching environment is very good and the material provided is ready to use with minimum effort from the teachers.
reviews.summary: Nice experience overall but very disorganised

reviews.advice: More integration between local and foreign staff.
reviews.cons: This is a stagnant culture and it starts to impact work on a daily basis. You are helped by the local staff, but then you owe them.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to share your experience. We're pleased to hear that our content and materials were useful and aided with your students' progress. We care a lot about our teachers' experience and ensuring that everyone receives training and support to be successful at work. We would be interested in learning more about your experience and ways we could improve. You may contact me directly at Mario.Bermeo@ef.com

reviews.pros: I taught for 2 years at a EF school in China. Their curriculum was very well thought out and each lesson plan contributed to the students' overall progress.  In my time there the school was still finding it's feet in the sense that foreign teacher needs were not realized. A strange country to work in, but worth it if you are only interested in money.
